thread.title: New $34 million pool and library in Christchurch's southwest edges closer
thread.title_full: New $34 million pool and library in Christchurch's southwest edges closer

author: Tina Law
title: New $34 million pool and library in Christchurch's southwest edges closer
text:
New $34 million pool and library in Christchurch's southwest edges closer TINA LAW Last updated 08:28, February 1 2017 DAVID WALKER/FAIRFAX NZ 
Denton Park on Main South Rd is one of the possible locations for a $34 million pool, library and service centre facility in Hornby. 
A new $34 million pool, library and service centre is edging closer to fruition in Christchurch's southwest. 
The Hornby and Sockburn communities have been waiting for years for a new pool facility, after the Sockburn pool was demolished by the Christchurch City Council in 2006. 
The council has set aside $34m for the project, but has yet to decide on a suitable location and whether to join the pool, library and service centre into one complex or build two separate facilities. DAVID WALKER/FAIRFAX NZ 
Kyle Park on Waterloo Rd has been named as a possible location for a $34 million pool, library and service centre facility in Hornby. 
A combined facility was preferred by the council because it would cost $2.5m less to build and would be $120,000 cheaper to operate annually. 
READ MORE: 
Three possible locations have been highlighted by council staff as the most suitable for the facility, including Denton Park, Kyle Park and Warren Park. DAVID WALKER/FAIRFAX NZ 
Warren Park on Wilmers Rd is one of the possible locations for a $34 million pool, library and service centre facility in Hornby. 
Council staff considered 16 sites and have ranked them based on access, location, cost and availability. Locations that needed to be purchased at a significant cost, were too small or could delay the project were given a low priority. 
In a report to the Halswell Hornby Riccarton Community Board, council recreation and sports head John Filsellâ€‹ said all of the identified sites had drawbacks, and there would not be a universally accepted ideal site. 
Community feedback would soon be sought before a final decision was made. 
"The project has progressed to a point where community engagement is essential to it proceeding any further." Ad Feedback 
Denton Park was deemed the most suitable by council staff, with a score of 80 per cent. It was a high profile site, at a good location and close to transport links. The council owned the land, but it was in high demand as a sports field. 
Kyle Park on Waterloo Rd scored 68 per cent, because it provided good access and room for expansion, but the loss of open space and sports grounds would need to be considered. 
Warren Park scored 62 per cent because it was not in a central location and was just 5 kilometres from the Halswell library and pool. 
A combined facility would be up to 4400 square metres, include a library, gym, indoor lane swimming and leisure water play areas, community meeting rooms, customer service facilities and areas for the council's community governance staff. 
Halswell Hornby Riccarton Community Board chairman Mike Mora said he wanted the project to proceed as fast as possible because the community had been waiting far too long already. 
"Hornby has been suffering from an acute lack of swimming facilities." 
Riccarton Ward councillor Vicki Buck said the southwest had grown dramatically since the Canterbury earthquakes and it was important everyone in the city had access to such facilities. 
It was hoped the project would be completed by mid-2019. - Stuff
